item.title: In front of the Guitar Guitar shop, towards Signmakers Yard, 6th February
item.description:
A manhole is sunken and rocking. Every time a car passes from Delancey St. they pass over that manhole due to road works narrowing the carriage on the other side of the street, and the manhole makes a very loud clanging sound every time a tyre passes over it. It's very disturbing to me and other residents with windows facing Delancey Street (despite the double-glazing) and presumably to residents of other nearby buildings as well and guests of the hotel on the corner. It's been going on for a few days now (at least 3 days).
Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): 9A, Delancey Street, Chalk Farm, Greater London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Flooding due to dip in road soaks bus stop passengers, 6th February
item.description:
Everytime it rains, water collects at the kerb line next to bus stop F on Westmoreland road. It stretches out into the live lane and cars go past soaking the bus stop and anyone who dares to wait for a bus. This has been ongoing for years. I have reported previously a year or two ago and it just got closed. The road is the issue. It dips heavily to the kerb with no drainage Bus passengers and pedestrians on the pavement shouldn’t have to run the risk of getting drenched going about their daily routine because of the state of the roads in poor weather
Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Westmoreland Road, Shortlands, Greater London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Repeated night-time parking facing oncoming traffic on 30 mph main road, 6th February
item.description:
On this 30 mph main road there is a recurring issue occurring primarily at night where a work van and other vehicles are repeatedly parking facing oncoming traffic. This unsafe behaviour is now being copied by additional drivers, creating a growing and ongoing road safety concern. Parking against the direction of traffic at night is contrary to the Highway Code (Rule 239) and is particularly hazardous on a busy main road. Vehicles parked in this manner obstruct sight lines, create glare for approaching traffic, and increase risk for vehicles pulling out when visibility is reduced. Given that this behaviour is frequent, predictable, and occurring on a main road under Greenwich Council’s responsibility, it is concerning that it appears to be going unenforced. The scale and regularity of this behaviour suggests that significant numbers of parking contraventions are occurring without enforcement, which in turn encourages further unsafe parking practices. I am requesting that parking enforcement assess this location and take appropriate action before this escalating behaviour results in an accident.

Nearest address to the pin placed on the map (from OS Places API): Footscray Road, Eltham
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Abandoned vehicle, 6th February
item.description:
This car has been parked in our private driveway since early last year tires are flat it’s not moved It’s now untaxed and without a MOT it has been reported to police who have explained it’s not stolen so cannot do anything Has been reported to Bromley who stated cannot do anything as it had road tax No body in this block of flats has expressed it is there car and it’s taking up space I’ve tried to report on DVLA and it’s brought me back to Bromley website.
Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Melbourne Court, Crystal Palace, Greater London
Report on FixMyStreet
